quizData.question: New technologies that are currently developing or will be developed over the next 5 to 10 years and which will substantially alter the business and social environment is called what?
AI was first developed in the 1950s, hence, it's not considered as Emerging Technology.
This characteristic of emerging technology says that emerging technology may take the form of progressing technology.
This characteristic of emerging technology says that emerging technologies are radically novel.
This characteristic of emerging technology says that emerging technology grow faster compared to non-emerging technologies?

This characteristic of emerging technology says that emerging technology is a convergence of previously separated research streams and technologies that have already moved beyond the purely conceptual stage.
This characteristic of emerging technology refers to the internal characteristics of a group being united and having logical interconnection.
This characteristic of emerging technology distinguish technologies that have acquired a certain identity and momentum from those still in a state of flux and, therefore, not yet emerging.
This characteristic of emerging technology says that emerging technology provides benefits for a wide range of sectors, transforms an industry, and exerts much enhanced economic influence.
This characteristic of emerging technology says that ambiguity arises because proposed applications are still malleable.
This characteristic of emerging technology says that even the knowledge of the emergence's possible outcome is incomplete.
This characteristic of emerging technology are key starting concepts for a variety of science and technological studies that focus on the role of the expectations in technological emergence.
Emerging technologies are also characterized by uncertainty.
This area of emerging technology overlays computer-generated display, sound, and effects on a user's view of the real world.
This area of emerging technology is a simulation of human intelligence process by machines.
This area of emerging technology uses a qubit as its basic unit of computation.
This is the application of AI that provides a machine with the ability to learn from experience like humans.
This is analogous to the standard bit (0 / 1) but is in a quantum superposition between 2 computational quantum states.
Which Industrial Revolution began in the 18th century?
Which Industrial Revolution is the introduction of mechanical production using hydroelectric and steam-powered equipment?
Which Industrial Revolution began in the 19th century?
Which Industrial Revolution uses electricity?
Which Industrial Revolution began with the first computer area?
Which Industrial Revolution uses electronics and IT to automate production processes?
Which Industrial Revolution involves the internet?
Which Industrial Revolution is the current and developing environment?
Which Industrial Revolution involves disruptive tech such as IoT, robotics, VR, AR, and AI?
Which Industrial Revolution leads changes in traditional relationships between humans and machines?
This building block of Industry 4.0 is the process of collecting, organizing, and analyzing large sets of data from different resources to discover patterns and other useful information.
This building block of Industry 4.0 supports real-time decision-making in production.
This building block of Industry 4.0 makes analyzing large data and immediately get answers possible.
This building block of Industry 4.0 describes the idea of everyday physical objects being connected to the Internet and being able to communicate and interact with other devices.
This building block of Industry 4.0 allows field devices to interact with one another and with more centralized controllers.
This building block of Industry 4.0 decentralizes analytics and decision-making.
This building block of Industry 4.0 refers to anything that involves delivering hosted services over the internet.
This building block of Industry 4.0 supports a variety of services, such as selecting parts in a warehouse and sending repair instructions over mobile devices.
This building block of Industry 4.0 is currently in its infancy.
What is the systematic process of defining, designing, testing, and implementing a new application?
What is the correct order of the fundamental phases in a software development project?
These are the roles of a system analyst EXCEPT ONE.
quizData.answer: Analyze the language of the development
choices: Analyze the language of the development
Create blueprints for how the system should be built

quizData.question: Its purpose is to convert high-level requirements defined from user requirements into a list of detailed requirements called a requirements definition report.
It can be used as inputs for creating models such as a functional model.
A statement of what the system must perform or what characteristic it must have.
This type of requirement are determined from client discussions that are refined in the design phase into system requirements.

Which word makes the statement wrong?
Requirements are written from the perspective of the developer's needs.
These requirements are directly related to the process a system has to perform or data it needs to contain.
These requirements directly flows into the creation of functional, structural, and behavioral models that represent the functionality of the system.
Functional, structural, and behavioral models are graphical representation that show how a system works.
These requirements pertain to behavioral properties that a system must have, including operational, performance, security, and cultural and political.
These requirements defines how a system is supposed to be or its system properties.
These requirements are primarily used in design when decisions are made about the database, UI, hardware, software, and system architecture.
These requirements affect decisions made during system design.
This type of non-functional requirements specify the operating environments in which the system must perform, as well as how these might change over time.
This type of non-functional requirements usually refers to OSes, system software, and information systems.
This type of non-functional requirements might also include the physical environment such as in what building area the system must be installed.
This type of non-functional requirements deals with issues related to performance such as response time, capacity, and reliability of the system.
This type of non-functional requirements addresses issues with security, such as who has access to system data and must have the ability to protect data from disruption or data loss.
This type of non-functional requirements deals with issues related to the cultural and political factors and legal requirements that affect the system.
This is another term for a Requirements Definition Report.
choices: The Magical Book of Wonder Requirements

quizData.question: This is a documentation that lists the functional and non-functional requirements of a system in an outline format that defines the scope of the system or software.
This is used to describe what the systems can do.

Which of the following statements are TRUE ?
I. It is best practice to include the words "shall" or "will" when writing requirements.
II. Functional requirements include requirements of how the users
III. Non-functional requirements include requirements that define how the system will operate and its characteristics.
choices: Statement I is FALSE , the rest are TRUE .
Statement II is TRUE , the rest is FALSE .

quizData.question: When discrepancies arise during software or system development, this document serves as a tool for clarification.
What is the process of cooperating with clients or users to determine what requirements are needed?
What Requirements Gathering Technique is the commonly used?
What Requirements Gathering Technique allows the project team, users, and management to work together to identify system requirements?
What Requirements Gathering Technique is a structured process that involves a group of participants to meet together under the direction of a facilitator?
What Requirements Gathering Technique involves is a set of written questions used to obtain information from individuals?
What Requirements Gathering Technique is often used when there is a large number of people from whom information and opinions are needed?
What Requirements Gathering Technique is a common technique with systems or software intended for use outside the organization?
What Requirements Gathering Technique is often used by project teams to understand the current system (as-is system) of an organization?
What Requirements Gathering Technique is a form of qualitative research in which documents are analyzed and interpreted by the researchers to give voice and meaning around an assessment topic?
What Requirements Gathering Technique involves the act of watching process being performed?
What Requirements Gathering Technique enables the analyst to see the reality of a situation rather than listening to others?
In an interview, the people interviewed are selected based on the analyst's information needs.
In an interview, what does the interview should have in order to anticipate possible answers and provide follow-up on them?
In an interview, what should be the interviewer's next step after conducting the interview?
choices: Prepare a spreadsheet of data spreads
Conduct a budget hearing, madam chair

quizData.question: In an interview, the interview report must contain the following EXCEPT ONE.
In JAD, which one sets meeting agenda and guides the discussion but doesn't join it?
In JAD, whch one must be an expert in both group-process techniques and systems and analysis design techniques?
In JAD, which one assists the facilitator by recording notes, making copies, and so on?
In JAD, which one can use computers and CASE tools to record information as the JAD session proceedings?
JAD sessions can take at most a day.
In conducting a JAD session, the JAD facilitator performs the key functions below EXCEPT ONE.
choices: Ensure that the group sticks to the agenda and follow the rules.
Help the group understand the terms and the analysis techniques used.
Record the group's input on a public display area.

quizData.question: Selecting participants for JAD must be based on the information they can contribute in order to provide a broad mixture of organization levels and build political support for the new system.
How long does a JAD report take to make?
After a questionnaire is handed out to participants, how long should a report be developed?
choices: At most a week after the deadline.

quizData.question: In designing interview questions, the following type of questions are usually combined together EXCEPT FOR ONE.
In an interview, the interview questions can be outside the areas of concern.

Which word makes the statement wrong?
The key issue in Document Analysis is many projects or systems are not well documented because the project teams who develop the systems fail to document their projects along the way.
choices: not well; it must be well.
Document Analysis; it must be Requirements Analysis.

quizData.question: What Requirements Gathering Technique is a good way to check the validity of information gathered from indirect sources such as interviews and questionnaires.
What are the 3 stages of the analysis process?
quizData.answer: As-is system, identifying improvements, to-be system.
choices: As-is system, identifying improvements, to-be system.
Gathering of feedback, analysis of possible actions, implementation.
Development of system, gathering of feedback, implementing improvements.

quizData.question: Interviews and JAD sessions are commonly used for the 3 stages of the analysis process.

What word makes the statement incorrect?
The document analysis and observation are helpful for understanding the to-be system - although they can occasionally provide info about current problems that needs improvement.
choices: document analysis; it must be requirements analysis.
current problems; it must be potential problems.

quizData.question:
What word makes the statement incorrect?
Questionnaires are used to gather info about the as-is system and general information about improvements.

This refers to how rich and detailed the information is that the technique usually produces and the extent to which the technique is useful for obtaining not only facts and opinions but an understanding of why those facts and opinions exist.
This refers to the range of information and sources that can be collected easily using the chosen technique.
One of the most challenging requirements-gathering is integrating the info from different sources.
This refers to the amount of time and energy the intended users of the new system must devote to the analysis process.
The cost of using each Requirements Gathering Technique is a determinant on its effectivity.
Requirements Gathering usually only uses one particular technique throughout the process.
Most analysts start by using interviews with senior managers to gain an understanding of the project and the key issues.
JAD sessions are commonly used when identifying improvements.
This is conducted after gathering data to determine if the specified requirements are actually required.

Which of the statements are TRUE ?
I. Requirements should be analyzed for the characteristics of good requirements and project teams.
II. Analysts may employ a checklist as a tool to determine if each requirement is actually required.
choices: I. is TRUE , II. is FALSE .
II. is TRUE , I. is FALSE .

quizData.question: What characteristic of a good requirement states that a requirement is needed or specifies an essential factor on the system?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that if the requirement is removed, a deficiency will exist that can't be achieved by other features of the system?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement should only be interpreted in 1 way?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement should be specific and easy to understand?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement shouldn't have conflicts with other requirements?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that any conflicts and overlaps between requirements must be determined and resolved?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement must completely describe the necessary functionality that will result to meet the user's need.
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement statement must only include 1 requirement with no use of conjunctions?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that statements with conjunctions such as "and", "or", and "but" must be reviewed carefully to see if they can be broken into singular requirements?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement must not contain multiple needs to avoid anomalies and to be able to be analyzable independently?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement must be achievable within system constraints such as time, costs, legal, and available resources?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement must be possible to be implemented?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement is verifiable if the implemented system or software can be tested to prove that the specified requirement has been met?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that different testing tools prove that the system satisfies the specified requirement?
What characteristic of a good requirement states that the requirement must have a unique identifier to track changes to it throughout the development cycle?
It is a list of questions which the analyst will use to assess each requirement.
After analyzing the requirements, the analyzed requirements must be systematically organized to create the requirements definition report and must be reviewed by the client for approval.
What contains revisions of the system until the client approves of the document?
This is a visual modeling language that provides a visual means of developing and documenting object-oriented software and systems.
What kind of diagram can be included in requirement definition report when defining functional requirements?
What component of use-case diagrams is person / system that represents the role of someone interacting with the system or software and is the user of the system?
What component of use-case diagrams represent the functionality of a system?
What component of use-case diagrams represent the system's scope of which a set of use-cases are applied?
What component of use-case diagrams specify that the actor interacts with the system and uses a certain functionality?
What component of use-case diagrams represent the required use of functionality of 1 use-case by another in order to perform its task?
What component of use-case diagrams indicate optional functionality under a certain use-case?
What component of use-case diagrams represent a specialized use-case to a more generalized one?
What component of use-case diagrams is represented by a stick figure?
What component of use-case diagrams is represented by an oblong?
What component of use-case diagrams is represented by a box?
What component of use-case diagrams is represented by a singular line between the actor and use-case.
What component of use-case diagrams is represented by a dashed arrow with an open arrowhead from the base use-case to the use-case?
What component of use-case diagrams is represented by a dashed arrow with an open arrowhead from the extending use-case to the base use-case?
What component of use-case diagrams is represented by an arrow drawn from the child use-case to the parent use-case?
If an actor represents a role played by a nonhuman, like an object, what is the keyword placed on the rectangle below the stick figure?
What type of actor initiates interaction with the system or software?
What type of actor is called upon by the system for support when the primary actor initiates an interaction with a use-case of the system?
A use-case diagram can have 1 primary actor and several primary and secondary actors.

What word makes the statement FALSE ?
Actors must be placed inside the subject boundary box as they produce and access data.
choices: subject boundary box; it must be use-case.

quizData.question: What component of use-case diagrams state that every use-case must be labeled with a descriptive verb-noun phrase that defines a functional requirement?
A use-case functionality is initiated by what?
Every use-case is required to be associated with 1 or more actors.
What component of use-case diagrams could be a system, software, a module / subsystem, or an individual business process?
Where would the subject be placed inside a Subject Boundary Box?
It's best practice to place the primary actors on the left side of the subject boundary box and the secondary actors must be placed on the right side of the box.
What component of use-case diagrams defines a base use-case with extending use-case that contains optional behavior?
In Generalization Relationship, the child use-case inherits properties and behavior of the parent use-case and may override the behavior of the parent.
What component of use-case diagrams is ised when there are common behaviors between 2 use-cases and specialized behavior specific to each use-case?
Design and development of software are performed in the design phase of the project. (TR or FL)
During development, there may be changes in the requirements document that could affect the development. (TR or FL)
What characteristic of bad design architecture states that software is <u>hard</u> to change because every change affects many parts of the software?
What characteristic of bad design architecture states that when applying changes, unexpected parts of the software <u>breaks</u>?
What characteristic of bad design architecture states that modules are <u>hard to reuse</u> in other software because they can't be extracted from the current one?
These are a set of guidelines to be followed that helps developers arrange methods and data structures into classes.
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that each software module, class, or interface should have <u>only 1 reason to change</u>?

What principle in the SOLID Principles states that for a software to be easy to change, the classes must be designed to <u>allow their behaviors to be changed</u> by adding new code rather than changing existing code?
What principle in the SOLID Principles was introduced by Barbara Liskov?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that the derived classes should be<u> substitutable </u>for their base classes to build a software from interchangeable modules or classes?
What principle in the SOLID Principles advises software designers to <u>avoid depending on things that they don't use</u>?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that flexible software are those with classes that <u>depend on abstract classes or interfaces</u>?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that classes with more than 1 responsibility should be broken down into smaller, single responsibility classes?

What principle in the SOLID Principles states that a class doesn't have to only have 1 method; rather, a class can have any number of members such as methods and instance variables as long as its members are related to only 1 single responsibility of the class?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that software modules, interfaces, or classes should be open for extension but closed for modification?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that when there are new requirements for the software, the new behavior must be added by deriving a new class without modifying the existing class?

What principle in the SOLID Principles suggests not to add functionality on the class that has already been tested and is working properly, but rather to extend that class for adding new functionality?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that when creating a new derived class of an existing class, make sure that the derived class can be a substitute for its base class?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that all the derived classes of a base class should be able to perform the same behavior of their base class without negative side effects?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that clients shouldn't be forced to implement interfaces they don't use?
What principle in the SOLID Principles states that the most flexible software systems are those in which source code dependencies refer only to abstractions, not to concretions?
How is the image above a violation of the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)?
quizData.answer: The Employee method consists of 3 responsbilities to 3 different actors.
choices: The Employee method consists of 3 responsbilities to 3 different actors.
The employee method consists of 3 users, instead of 1.

quizData.question: How is the image above a proper implementation of the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)?
quizData.answer: The Employee class' responsibilities have been separated into different classes.
choices: The Employee class' responsibilities have been separated into different classes.
The Accounting, HumanResource, and DatabaseAdministrator classes uses the EmployeeData class.
The Accounting personnel, HR personnel, and Database Administrator actors have their own methods.
The Accounting personnel, HR personnel, and Database Administrator actors has their own unique methods.

quizData.question: How is the image above a violation of the Open-Closed Principle (OCP)?
quizData.answer: The BankAccount class has to be modified every time a new type of bank account has to be added.
choices: The BankAccount class has to be modified every time a new type of bank account has to be added.
There are separate methods for creating a new account, when there could only really be one.
There are separate methods for depositing and withdrawing, when there could only really be one.
It's staring at me, menacingly. And I don't like it.

quizData.question: How is the image above a proper implementation of the Open-Closed Principle (OCP)?
quizData.answer: BankAccount had been abstracted and is now closed for modification but open for extension.
choices: BankAccount had been abstracted and is now closed for modification but open for extension.
The responsibilities of the BankAccount class had been separated into its own classes.
There are separate withdraw() methods for each kind of bank account.
We gave BankAccount two companion classes so it doesn't have to be lonely.

quizData.question: How is the image above a proper implementation of the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)?
quizData.answer: The behavior of Billing doesn't depend on any of the 2 derived classes, but both of the derived classes can substitute License.
choices: The behavior of Billing doesn't depend on any of the 2 derived classes, but both of the derived classes can substitute License.
The Billing class was replaced, hence, 'substituted' by the License class.
The License class has 2 separate classes for each license type.
The Billing and PersonalLicense classes don't have any methods, and is both lonely. Hence, they can substitute each other and no one can tell they're empty inside.

quizData.question: How is the image above a violation of the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)?
quizData.answer: The OnlineOrderProcessor and CashOnDeliveryOrderProcessor classes implement the same IOrderProcessor interface, forcing both of them to implement the methods within even when some of them aren't needed for their necessary functions.
choices: The OnlineOrderProcessor and CashOnDeliveryOrderProcessor classes implement the same IOrderProcessor interface, forcing both of them to implement the methods within even when some of them aren't needed for their necessary functions.
The IOrderProcessor uses both the classes even if only one is really needed.
The IOrderProcessor has multiple methods even if it only needs one.

quizData.question: How is the image above a proper implementation of the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)?
quizData.answer: The functions for both the COD and Online payment interfaces are separated, and the classes only implement the interfaces whose methods they need to function.
choices: The functions for both the COD and Online payment interfaces are separated, and the classes only implement the interfaces whose methods they need to function.
The IOrderProcessor and IOnlineOrderProcessors have singular responsibilities.
The OnlineOrderProcessor implements the IOrderProcessor as needed.

quizData.question: How is the image above a violation of the Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)?
quizData.answer: When the requirements of EmailNotifier changes, UserManager needs to be modified to change the new notification class.
choices: When the requirements of EmailNotifier changes, UserManager needs to be modified to change the new notification class.
The UserManager uses the EmailNotifier instead of through a proxy.
When the EmailNotifier code changes, the UserManager needs to change as well to cope with the EmailNotifier's modifications.
Di talaga mahal ni UserManager si EmailNotifier. Ginagamit nya lang sya.

quizData.question: How is the image above a proper implementation of the Dependency Inversion (DIP)?
quizData.answer: The UserManager, EmailNotifier, SMSNotifier, and PopupNotifier depend on the INotifier interface, so that when the requirements for the notification feature changes, it won't affect UserManager.
choices: The UserManager, EmailNotifier, SMSNotifier, and PopupNotifier depend on the INotifier interface, so that when the requirements for the notification feature changes, it won't affect UserManager.
The notification system had been split into separate responsibilities.
The UserManager doesn't directly interact with the notification system, employing the use of the interface as to prevent any code hardlocks.

quizData.question: These started as best practices in the industry that were applied to similar problems in different contexts multiple times.
These are templates or blueprints that any developer can customize to solve recurring design problems in code.
Design Patterns are a specific piece of code and not a general concept for solving a particular problem. (TR or FL)
This essential feature of Design Patterns is the name of the pattern used to describe a design problem, its solution, and consequences.
This essential feature of Design Patterns describes when to use the pattern.
This essential feature of Design Patterns explains the problem and its context.
This essential feature of Design Patterns describes the elements that make up the design, their relationships, responsibilities, and collaborations.
This essential feature of Design Patterns state that the pattern provides an abstract description of a design problem and how a general arrangement of element solves it.
This essential feature of Design Patterns is the results and interchanges of applying the pattern to the problem.
This essential feature of Design Patterns includes the time and space tradeoffs, but also flexibility, extensibility, and portability, among others.
What category of Design Patterns deals with when and how objects are created?
choices: Patawad, Amanai. Subalit hindi man lang ako nakakaalam ng sagot ngayon. Wala akong inaaral kahit saan man. Ngayon lang kasi'y parang napakaganda ng mundo. Mula sa langit at lupa, ako lamang ang pinarangalan.

quizData.question: What category of Design Patterns provides object creation mechanisms that increase flexibility and reuse of existing codes?

What category of Design Patterns describe how objects are composed into larger groups and explain how to assemble objects and classes into larger structures while keeping their structures flexible and efficient?
What category of Design Patterns describe how responsibilities are distributed between objects in the design and how communication happens between objects?
What category of Design Patterns is all about class instantiation?
What category of Design Patterns deals with object mechanisms, trying to create objects in a manner suitable to a certain situation?
What category of Design Patterns deal with the arrangement and relationship between the classes in the software system?
What category of Design Patterns is all about grouping classes together and providing ways for objects to coordinate to get work done?
What category of Design Patterns can also control and grant access to an object and add new functionalities to existing objects?
What category of Design Patterns is concerned with how classes and objects behave in a system software and how objects communicate with each other?
What category of Design Patterns describe how to assign behavioral responsibilities to classes?
What Creational Pattern ensures that a class <u>only has 1 instance </u>while providing a global access point to the instance?
What Creational Pattern <u>provides an interface for creating objects</u> in a superclass but allows subclasses to alter the type of object that will be created?
What Creational Pattern lets a developer <u>copy existing objects without making the code dependent on their classes</u>?
What Creational Pattern allows developers to <u>produce families of related objects without specifying their concrete classes</u>?
What Creational Pattern allows developers to <u>construct complex objects step by step</u>?
What Creational Pattern allows developers to <u>produce different types and representations of an object using the same construction code</u>?
What Structural Pattern allows objects with<u> incompatible interfaces to collaborate</u>?
What Structural Pattern <u>converts the interface of a class into another interface </u>as expected by the client application?

What Structural Pattern allows developers to <u>split a large class or a set of closely related classes into 2 separate hierarchies, which are abstraction and implementation</u>, that can be developed independently of each other.
What Structural Pattern allows developers to <u>compose objects into tree structures</u> and then work with these structures treating them as individual objects.
What Structural Pattern allows developers to attach new behaviors to objects by <u>placing these objects inside special wrapper objects </u>that contain the behaviors.
What Structural Pattern provides a <u>simplified interface</u> to a library, a framework, or any other complex set of classes.

What Structural Pattern allows developers to <u>fit more objects into the available amount of RAM </u>by sharing common parts of state between multiple objects instead of keeping all of the data in each other.
What Structural Pattern allows developers to <u>provide a substitute</u> or placeholder for another object?
What Behavioral Pattern allows developers to <u>traverse elements of a collection</u> without exposing its underlying representation, such as list, stack, and tree?
What Behavioral Pattern is used for <u>sequentially iterating </u>and accessing items from a collection of items?
What Behavioral Pattern allows developers to define a <u>subscription mechanism</u> to notify multiple objects about any events that happen to the object they are observing?
What Behavioral Pattern states that when an object changes state, <u>all of its dependents are notified and updated automatically</u>?
What Behavioral Pattern allows developers to <u>define a family of algorithms</u>, put each of them into a separate class, and make their objects interchangeable?
The Singleton's constructor should be hidden from the client code. (TR or FL)
In the Prototype Pattern, the Prototype interface declares the cloning methods. (TR or FL)
In the Prototype Pattern, what class implements the cloning method?
In the Prototype Pattern, what class provides an easy way to access frequently used prototypes?
In the Factory Method Pattern, what class returns products of a particular kind?
In the Builder Pattern, what class degines the order of building step execution?
In the Builder Pattern, what class provides the implementation for the building steps?
In the Builder Pattern, what class are the resulting objects constructed by the Builder class?
In the Adapter Pattern, what class implements the client interface while wrapping the service object?
In the Component Pattern, what interface describes the operations that are common to both simple and complex elements of the tree?

In the Facade Pattern, what class provides convenient access to a particular part of the subsystem's functionality and knows where to direct the client's request and how to operate all the moving parts?
In the Flyweight Pattern, what are values that remain constant?
In the Flyweight Pattern, what are values that may always change?
In the Proxy Pattern, which controls access to the original object, allowing developers to perform something before or after the requests gets through to the original object?
In the Iterator Pattern, what class encapsulates all of the traversal details, such as the current position and how many elements are left until the end?
In the Observer Pattern, what object notifies other objects about the changes to its state?
In the Observer Pattern, what are the objects called that want to track changes to the publisher's state?
choices: Patawad, Amanai. Subalit hindi man lang ako nakakaalam ng sagot ngayon. Wala akong inaaral kahit saan man. Ngayon lang kasi'y parang napakaganda ng mundo. Mula sa langit at lupa, ako lamang ang pinarangalan.

quizData.question: In the Observer Pattern, what class issues events of interests to other objects?
choices: Patawad, Amanai. Subalit hindi man lang ako nakakaalam ng sagot ngayon. Wala akong inaaral kahit saan man. Ngayon lang kasi'y parang napakaganda ng mundo. Mula sa langit at lupa, ako lamang ang pinarangalan.

quizData.question: In the Observer Pattern, what interface declares the notification interface?
choices: Patawad, Amanai. Subalit hindi man lang ako nakakaalam ng sagot ngayon. Wala akong inaaral kahit saan man. Ngayon lang kasi'y parang napakaganda ng mundo. Mula sa langit at lupa, ako lamang ang pinarangalan.

quizData.question: This pertains to the degree to which a software product meets the gathered requirements.

These are a set  of activities that define and assess the adequacy of software process to provide evidence which establishes confidence that the software processes are appropriate for and product software products of suitable quality for their intended processes.
These are based on the planning and implementation of a series of activities for ensuring quality in the software development process.
This is a structured approach to improve software quality.
This involves defect prevention, detection, and removal, as well as defect containment activities.
Which reasons driving software quality assurance states that bugs can have immediate impacts on clients or customers?
Which reasons driving software quality assurance states that poor quality software tend to be expensive to develop and maintain and can negatively affect organizations?

Which reasons driving software quality assurance states that the development and use of software might require certification, which often require evidence of the application of various quality control and assessment measures?
Which reasons driving software quality assurance states that there may be overriding legal obligations that apply to organizations that use the software?
Which reasons driving software quality assurance states that every practicable measure must be taken to demonstrate that the software system doesnt pose a risk to its users?

Which reasons driving software quality assurance states that in cases where software systems arent covered by software certification and legislation, and where its failure is not necessarily business or safety-critical, there can remain moral obligation to the users?

Which reasons driving software quality assurance states that software engineers should do whatever is possible to maximize the quality of their software and to prevent it from containing harmful bugs?
This is the act of building software application prototypes which displays the functionality of the product under development, but may not actually hold the exact logic of the original software.
This act moves the quality assurance earlier and makes it easier.
All of these is achieved by software prototyping EXCEPT ONE.
choices: Allow users to evaluate the software system design and how the software actually works.
Clarify the functionalities of the software to both users and developers.
Reduce the need to recreate the software system due to some gaps on the implementation.

quizData.question: What prototyping paradigm is a relatively fast method of prototyping that focuses on employing prototypes to generate insights about the software design idea?
What prototyping paradigm states that created prototypes are discarded after testing and after obtaining feedback?
What prototyping paradigm are used in early design stages where the gathered requirements are still unclear?
What prototyping paradigm states that prototypes are reused after the testing in a way that they are altered to the test results and then reused in a new test cycle?
What prototyping paradigm is used in late development stages where sufficient insights about principle design decisions exist and the prototype addresses technical and long-term use issues?
Prototype fidelity pertains to how it conveys the look and feel of the final product. (TR or FR)
What fidelity of prototyping states that its role is to check and test the visual appearance and user flows of a software?
What fidelity of prototyping does throwaway prototyping fall into?
What fidelity of prototyping is created when developers have a solid understanding of what theyre going to build?
What fidelity of prototyping states the need to test it with actual users?
What fidelity of prototyping does evolutionary prototyping fall into?
What fidelity of prototyping is created in the form of programming codes and IDEs?
What technique in creating low-fidelity prototypes is used to create a prototype based on hand drawings that represent UI of the software?
What technique in creating low-fidelity prototypes allows developers to explore ideas and refine designs quickly?
What is the visual representation of a product page that developers can use to arrange pages of user interfaces?
What technique in creating low-fidelity prototypes makes use of tools such as Balsamiq Wireframes, Axure, MockFlow, Adobe XD, and Figma?
This is a formalized peer review process for detecting and correcting defects or bugs in software artifacts.
Its objective is to help developers build quality into the software product.
These are anything that have been documented and stored during the software development process such as requirements document, source code, user documentation, test plans, and test cases.
This software inspection technique is developed by Michael Fagan. (Pag ito namali mo pa ewan ko nalang)
This software inspection technique identifies and removes errors in the software products and to identify any systematic defects in the processes that are used to create software products.
This software inspection technique requires that software artifacts be formally inspected by experts independent of the author.
This software inspection technique includes roles namely, moderator, author, reader, and tester.
This software inspection technique is a peer review in which the author of a deliverable, such as a document or source code, brings 1 or more reviewers through the deliverable.
This software inspection technique's objective is to get feedback from the reviewers on the quality of the document or code and to familiarize the review audience with the authors work.
This software inspection technique includes several roles, namely, the review leader, author, scribe, and the review audience.
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspector role leads the inspection team and takes care of logistics?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspector role is the creator of the software artifacts under inspection?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspector role actively answers all the questions regarding the artifacts during the inspection meeting?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspector role is responsible for fixing identified defects and bugs in the artifacts?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspector role is an experienced peer who can be a subject matter expert on the software artifacts under inspection?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspector role is responsible for writing and executing test cases for the software module or product?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspector role is focused on how the product would be tested?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which activity involves identifying the inspector and roles, along with arranging the meeting place and time?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which activity involves briefing of participants on information of materials?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which activity involves preparation for the meeting and reading through the deliverables?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which activity involves the moderator setting the time limit for inspection and recording and classifying defects?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which activity involves improving the development and inspection process along with making recommendation to the process improvement team?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which activity involves the author correcting the defects and carries out any necessary investigations?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which activity involves the moderator verifying that the author has resolved the defects and investigations?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspection type finds defects in the requirements and confirming if those are correct?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspection type finds defects in the design and confirming if those are correct with respect to the requirements?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspection type finds defects in the code and confirming if those are correct with respect to the design and requirements?
In Fagan Inspection Methodology, which inspection type finds defects in the test cases or plan, and confirming if those can verify the design and requirements?
This is an act of systematically convening with fellow programmers to check each others code for faults to ensure it meets quality standards.
This Code Reviewing Technique uses automated code analysis techniques that can pick out problematic patterns within the source code.

This Code Reviewing Technique states that the nature of the code problems that can be identified varies from 1 tool to another and depends to an extent on the nature of the underlying programming language.
This Code Reviewing Technique states that automated tools are especially good at identifying problems that are relatively localized to a single method or class.
This Code Reviewing Technique is where the developers themselves review code to pick out problems.
This Code Reviewing Technique is where reviewers manually assess codes before deployment.
This Code Reviewing Technique is usually a 2-step process where the developers have to understand the program first so that they can form an opinion of its implementation and design.
This is a lightweight variant of code inspections because it doesnt rely on face-to-face meetings.
This Modern Code Review technique uses Google Gerrit or Microsoft CodeFlow.
This is a central file storage location used by version control systems to store multiple versions of files that can be accessed by multiple users.
This Modern Code Review technique doesn't use code reviewing tools and revolves around a mechanism known as a pull request.
It is an activity of executing a system or component under specified conditions, observing or recording the results, and evaluating some of the aspects of the system or component.
It is an approach used for detecting defects in software and confirming that requirements are correctly implemented before deploying the software.

Is this Objective of Software Testing Direct or Indirect?
To identify and reveal as many errors as possible in tested software.

Is this Objective of Software Testing Direct or Indirect?
To bring the tested software to an acceptable level of quality after correcting the identified errors and retesting.

Is this Objective of Software Testing Direct or Indirect?
To perform the required tests efficiently and effectively and within the budgetary and scheduling limitations.

Is this Objective of Software Testing Direct or Indirect?
To establish with a degree of confidence that the software package is ready for delivery or installment at customer premises.

Is this Objective of Software Testing Direct or Indirect?
To compile a record of software errors for use in software process improvement by corrective and preventive actions and for decision-making.
Which of the following best describes Unit Testing?
quizData.answer: Performed by the developer on the completed unit or module of the software and before its integration with other modules.
choices: Performed by the developer on the completed unit or module of the software and before its integration with other modules.
The project team performs this type of testing on the integrated systems once all of the individual units work correctly in insolation.
Its objective is to verify that all of the modules and their interfaces work correctly together and to identify and resolve any issues.
Benefits from an existing enterprise architecture that provides information on all existing systems and their alignment with each other.

This phase partitions the requirements into hardware or software systems and builds the overall system architecture.

This is a software artifact with a set of test inputs, execution conditions, and expected results developed for a particular objective, such as to exercise a particular program path to verify compliance with a specific requirement and as documentation for a test item.
This comprise of user inputs that are provided to the application and the procedure for executing the test case during the test.

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
Name and number to identify a test case.

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
The reason for the test (may include the type of test).

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
The activities or steps required on the part of the tester to carry out the test.

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
Data to enter the system (made up of valid and invalid sets of test data).

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
Expected results of the test.

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
Placeholder for recording the actual result as the test case gets executed.

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
Determines whether the test was a Pass, Fail, or Not Executed.

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
Any comments on the test case or execution.

In the General Test Case Format, what component is being described below?
May include the name of the tester carrying out the tests, date of execution of the test, the environment in which the test was executed such as hardware and software.
If all tests pass in a Unit Test, the production code in testing is considered to be working - meeting its requirements. (TR or FL)
If even 1 test fails in a Unit Test, the production code is deemed to not meet its requirements. (TR or FL)
In unit testing, test cases are used to evaluate the input and expected output of the unit. (TR or FL)
